image.altText: Several small buildings in a row, that have all been badly damaged

items.synopsis: US President Joe Biden will travel to Israel on Wednesday, as Hamas releases a video of a 21-year-old hostage who is asking to be returned to her family as quickly as possible. Follow live.

title.children: Joe Biden set to visit Israel on Wednesday as Hamas releases video of 21-year-old hostage

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hamas has released a video of a young woman who is understood to be held hostage in the Gaza Strip. The video was posted on Hamas' Telegram channel and shows a young woman with a bandaged arm speaking Hebrew. She says her name is Mia Schem, she is 21 years old and from Shoham, near Tel Aviv. In the video she asks to be returned to her family as quickly as possible. A representative of the family, which was among a group of French families that appealed last week to President Emmanuel Macron to help free their missing relatives, confirmed her identity to Reuters. The Israel Defense Forces reacted to the video and said that Schem's family was notified of her abduction last week and that they are in continuous contact with them at this time. "In the video, Hamas is trying to portray itself as a humane organization, while it is a responsible for the murder and abduction of babies, women, children, and elderly," the IDF statement said. It is not known when or where the video was recorded. ABC/Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas releases video of 21-year-old hostage

children.content: Hamas has released a video of a young woman who is understood to be held hostage in the Gaza Strip.
The video was posted on Hamas' Telegram channel and shows a young woman with a bandaged arm speaking Hebrew. She says her name is Mia Schem, she is 21 years old and from Shoham, near Tel Aviv.

props.alt: Image of a girl with long blond hair sitting on a couch, behind her is a red blanket.

children.content: The subtitles on the screenshot read 'I am currently in Gaza'
(Telegram)
In the video she asks to be returned to her family as quickly as possible.

A representative of the family, which was among a group of French families that appealed last week to President Emmanuel Macron to help free their missing relatives, confirmed her identity to Reuters.
The Israel Defense Forces reacted to the video and said that Schem's family was notified of her abduction last week and that they are in continuous contact with them at this time.

props.alt: A girl is pictured lying down as her arm is being bandaged by someone wearing gloves.

children.content: In the video an injury to Schem's arm is being bandaged
(Telegram)
"In the video, Hamas is trying to portray itself as a humane organization, while it is a responsible for the murder and abduction of babies, women, children, and elderly," the IDF statement said.
It is not known when or where the video was recorded.
ABC/Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US President Joe Biden will travel to Israel on Wednesday (local time), his Secretary of State has confirmed. Antony Blinken has been in discussions with Israeli leaders, including Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. He says the US and Israel "have agreed to develop a plan that will enable humanitarian aid from donor nations and multilateral organisations to reach civilians in Gaza". "It is critical that aid begin flowing into Gaza as soon as possible," Mr Blinken says. "We share Israel's concern that Hamas may seize or destroy aid entering Gaza or otherwise prevent it from reaching the people who need it. "If Hamas in any way blocks humanitarian assistance from reaching civilians including by seizing the aid itself, we'll be the first to come to condemn it and work to prevent it from happening again. "The president very much looks forward to discussing it further when he's here on Wednesday." Other talking points flagged by Mr Blinken include the US reaffirming its commitment "that Israel has the right to defend its people from Hamas". He says Mr Biden will send a "crystal clear message" that no other nation should "take advantage of this crisis to attack Israel". "To that end, [Mr Biden] has deployed two aircraft carrier groups and other military assets to the region," Mr Blinken says. The release of hostages and a "comprehensive brief on Israel's war aims and strategy" are also on the agenda. White House National Security Council spokesman John Kirby says Mr Biden will travel to Jordan after his trip to Israel to meet with King Abdullah, Egyptian President Abdel Fattah el-Sissi and Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Joe Biden to travel to Israel on Wednesday, before meeting Palestinian President

props.alt: US President Joe Biden and Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu sit on stage at the UNited Nations General Assembly.

children.content: Benjamin Netanyahu and Joe Biden at the United Nations General Assembly in September.
(Reuters, file photo)

He says the US and Israel "have agreed to develop a plan that will enable humanitarian aid from donor nations and multilateral organisations to reach civilians in Gaza".

"We share Israel's concern that Hamas may seize or destroy aid entering Gaza or otherwise prevent it from reaching the people who need it.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: "Unfortunately" bang. "Did you hear that?" ABC Global Affairs Editor John Lyons didn't expect explosions to go off as during an on-air interview, as he was giving an update from aid workers. But that's exactly what happened as he explained to News Radio's Tom Oriti how he has 25 seconds to get to safety if he hears air sirens go off near where he is reporting from in Ashdod, southern Israel. The explosion can be heard at about 1:30 in the video. "While we're talking  I can see a missile, I think it's an Iron Dome missile going up to hit a probably incoming Hamas missile from the Gaza Strip," he said. "In fact I just heard a bang go off. so we've had a fairly heavy day even here in Ashdod." Lyons then went on to explain how he raced to safety in a stairwell after sirens went off the previous night and how he found himself in a stairwell with four Israel soldiers dressed in their underwear. On hearing another massive big bang, Lyons told Oriti he believed that was the sound of missiles exploding. "Did you hear that?" I'm not sure what that is actuallythe bang we just heard must have been the one I just heard hitting the missile coming in from Gaza. What that does is it explodes the incoming missile so in fact the two missiles are exploding.. but that shook things a bit that was a pretty confronting sound."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Explosions go off during a live update from ABC Global Affairs Editor John Lyons in Israel

items.synopsis: The resounding No vote in Western Australiahas been met with relief by many who say it was a distraction, including those in the Wheatbelt town of Darkan. Butothers say there will be ramifications for reconciliation.

title.children: Almost 90 per cent of people in this WA farming town voted No. Here's why

items.synopsis: Follow live as we bring you the latest updates from the Voice referendum fallout, for Tuesday October 17.

title.children: Former US ambassador says Voice referendum rejection will be a concern for Asia-Pacific region

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan has told ABC News the failure of the Voice to Parliament referendum over the weekend won't affect the state's approach to reconciliation. The Victorian government has been pursuing a state-based truth-telling process and treaty separate to the proposed federal Voice to Parliament, which was voted down in a national referendum on Saturday. Ms Allan says there has been bipartisan support for Victoria's approach. "We have been for some time now on a really clear path to how we can better listen and work with Indigenous Victorians to get better outcomes and we will continue on that path."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Victorian Premier says Voice referendum rejection won't impact state's reconcilliation

children.content: Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan has told ABC News the failure of the Voice to Parliament referendum over the weekend won't affect the state's approach to reconciliation.

The Victorian government has been pursuing a state-based truth-telling process and treaty separate to the proposed federal Voice to Parliament, which was voted down in a national referendum on Saturday.
Ms Allan says there has been bipartisan support for Victoria's approach.
"We have been for some time now on a really clear path to how we can better listen and work with Indigenous Victorians to get better outcomes and we will continue on that path."
Jacinta Allan says there has been bipartsian support for Victoria's approach.
(ABC News)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's former ambassador to the United States John McCarthy has told ABC News the rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament will be viewed negatively in the Asia-Pacific region. Sixty per cent of Australians voted against enshrining a Voice in the Constitution at the weekend. Mr McCarthy says the 'No' result will be a concern for Australia's Pacific neighbours. "People don't look at all the intricacies of the No vote but what they do see is a rejection of Indigenous aspirations in Australia by a majority of people in Australia, so it's as stark as that and that will have an adverse impact in the way we are regarded more generally I think, globally."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former US ambassador says Voice referendum rejection will be a concern for the Asia-Pacific region

children.content: Australia's former ambassador to the United States
John
McCarthy
has told ABC News the rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament will be viewed negatively in the Asia-Pacific region.
Sixty per cent of Australians voted against enshrining a Voice in the Constitution at the weekend.
Mr McCarthy says the 'No' result will be a concern for Australia's Pacific neighbours.

"People don't look at all the intricacies of the No vote but what they do see is a rejection of Indigenous aspirations in Australia by a majority of people in Australia, so it's as stark as that and that will have an adverse impact in the way we are regarded more generally I think, globally."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy says many are "deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians" after the country voted against a Voice to Parliament. When asked by ABC's RN Breakfast if Australia "got it right" in terms of the outcome of the referendum, Ms McCarthy says she finds it "deeply disappointing" Australians don't want a Voice to Parliament. "It's not right as a First Nations person to have to keep explaining why your history is important in this country and why we have been here for over 65,000 years." Ms McCarthy says there is still urgency to address issues for First Nations people, but there needs to be some time to regroup and recover first. "People are feeling absolutely hurt right now. Deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians. "They need time to mourn as the First Nations have said in terms of their silence this week." Listen to the full interview here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians says many are 'deeply disappointed'

featuredLink.title: Malarndirri McCarthy on the Voice: 'I think we could have been better' - ABC listen

children.content: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy says many are "deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians" after the country voted against a Voice to Parliament.

When asked by ABC's RN Breakfast if Australia "got it right" in terms of the outcome of the referendum, Ms McCarthy says she finds it "deeply disappointing" Australians don't want a Voice to Parliament.
"It's not right as a First Nations person to have to keep explaining why your history is important in this country and why we have been here for over 65,000 years."
Ms McCarthy says there is still urgency to address issues for First Nations people, but there needs to be some time to regroup and recover first.
"People are feeling absolutely hurt right now. Deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians.
"They need time to mourn as the First Nations have said in terms of their silence this week."
Listen to the full interview here.

items.synopsis: A rallyon Wall Streetsends Australian stocks higher, while minutes of the Reserve Bank's October meeting show theboard considered hiking rates.Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX rises, RBA considered raising rates in October meeting, Wall Street rallies

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, led by miners after Rio Tinto reported a rise in quarterly production. The ASX 200 climbed 0.5 per cent or 34 points, to 7,061, by 12:48pm AEDT. Heavyweight miners rose 0.7 per cent, driven by a 1.6 per cent jump in Rio Tinto as the world's biggest iron ore producer reported a 1.2 per cent rise in its third-quarter iron ore shipments. Miners were also helped by an increase in iron ore futures on Monday as investor sentiment was boosted by fresh China stimulus. Financials climbed 0.8 per cent, with the big four banks rising between 0.7 per cent and 0.9 per cent. Tech stocks advanced 1.9 per cent, after the tech-heavy Nasdaq closed 1.2 per cent higher overnight. Gold stocks were up 0.2 per cent. Shares of Newcrest Mining gained 0.4 per cent even after the country's largest gold miner reported an 18.1 per cent sequential fall in quarterly gold production, hurt by maintenance shutdowns.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still tracking higher in afternoon trade

children.content: Australian shares have risen in afternoon trade, led by miners after Rio Tinto reported a rise in quarterly production.
The ASX 200 climbed 0.5 per cent or 34 points, to 7,061, by 12:48pm AEDT.
Heavyweight miners rose 0.7 per cent, driven by a 1.6 per cent jump in Rio Tinto as the world's biggest iron ore producer reported a 1.2 per cent rise in its third-quarter iron ore shipments.
Miners were also helped by an increase in iron ore futures on Monday as investor sentiment was boosted by fresh China stimulus.
Financials climbed 0.8 per cent, with the big four banks rising between 0.7 per cent and 0.9 per cent.
Tech stocks advanced 1.9 per cent, after the tech-heavy Nasdaq closed 1.2 per cent higher overnight.

Gold stocks were up 0.2 per cent. Shares of Newcrest Mining gained 0.4 per cent even after the country's largest gold miner reported an 18.1 per cent sequential fall in quarterly gold production, hurt by maintenance shutdowns.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minutes from the Reserve Bank's October meeting show the board considered hiking rates but judged that there was not enough new information to warrant a hike. Minutes also show the board was concerned that inflation was not slowing as hoped, suggesting a chance the 4.1 per cent cash rate could be lifted next month. The RBA currently assumes that inflation will not return to its 2-3 per cent target band until late 2025. As a result, the board reiterated that some further tightening may be required to bring inflation down Rates have already risen by 400 basis points to an 11-year high and the RBA judged the full effects of that tightening were yet to be felt. A recent rise in petrol prices could influence inflation expectations. The key inflation report for the third quarter is out on October 25. Markets currently imply only a 16 per cent chance of a hike in November, but that would increase should inflation surprise on the high side. The board was also concerned that the sustained rebound in housing prices could be a signal that the currency policy stance was not as restrictive as had been assumed and could be supporting household consumption. On the other side of the arguments, the labour market has reached a turning point, output growth has slowed and it would take some time for the full effects of the tightening so far to be observed in the data. Required mortgage payments increased to 9.9 per cent of the household disposable income in August, above the previous estimated historical peak. Reporting by Alicia Barry
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA considered raising rates in October policy meeting

children.content: Minutes from the Reserve Bank's October meeting show the board considered hiking rates but judged that there was not enough new information to warrant a hike.
Minutes also show the board was concerned that inflation was not slowing as hoped, suggesting a chance the 4.1 per cent cash rate could be lifted next month.
The RBA currently assumes that inflation will not return to its 2-3 per cent target band until late 2025.
As a result, the board reiterated that some further tightening may be required to bring inflation down
Rates have already risen by 400 basis points to an 11-year high and the RBA judged the full effects of that tightening were yet to be felt.
A recent rise in petrol prices could influence inflation expectations. The key inflation report for the third quarter is out on October 25.
Markets currently imply only a 16 per cent chance of a hike in November, but that would increase should inflation surprise on the high side.

The board was also concerned that the sustained rebound in housing prices could be a signal that the currency policy stance was not as restrictive as had been assumed and could be supporting household consumption.

On the other side of the arguments, the labour market has reached a turning point, output growth has slowed and it would take some time for the full effects of the tightening so far to be observed in the data.
Required mortgage payments increased to 9.9 per cent of the household disposable income in August, above the previous estimated historical peak.
Reporting by Alicia Barry

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rabobank has released its 2023/24 Australian Winter Crop Forecast, showing Australian grain and oilseed production is set to return to more modest totals for the current season as drier growing conditions "hit home". It says Australia is on track to harvest a total winter crop of 48.72 million tonnes for the current season. While down 24 per cent on last seasons record-breaking 63.85 million tonne national crop, this is still close to the five-year average and above totals recorded in 2018/19 and 2020/21. And prices are expected to provide some silver lining to the lower production totals for Australian farmers, says report co-author, RaboResearch associate analyst Edward McGeoch, with dry conditions in Australia pushing local prices above those globally, to a "positive basis" for wheat and also barley. While global export demand should also be supportive of canola prices. Mr McGeoch says drier weather conditions that have spread across many cropping regions in the country and the prevailing El Nino climate outlook are playing a significant role in the tighter supply outlook for Australian grain and oilseeds. Production expectations are varied across regions with some farmers expecting to see elevated production due to positive growing conditions they have experienced while others will be facing tough decisions as to whether it will be worth harvesting their crop, he said. The bank says all cereal and coarse grain production  including wheat, barley and oats  is expected to decrease this season, with wheat declining the furthest, down to 26.9 million tonnes. Winter crop production is expected to decline across all states, except Victoria, where the bank sees it rising by eight per cent from last year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Winter crop production down, but prices provide silver lining: Rabobank

children.content: Rabobank has released its 2023/24 Australian Winter Crop Forecast, showing Australian grain and oilseed production is set to return to more modest totals for the current season as drier growing conditions "hit home".

It says Australia is on track to harvest a total winter crop of 48.72 million tonnes for the current season. While down 24 per cent on last seasons record-breaking 63.85 million tonne national crop, this is still close to the five-year average and above totals recorded in 2018/19 and 2020/21.

And prices are expected to provide some silver lining to the lower production totals for Australian farmers, says report co-author, RaboResearch associate analyst Edward McGeoch, with dry conditions in Australia pushing local prices above those globally, to a "positive basis" for wheat and also barley. While global export demand should also be supportive of canola prices.

Mr McGeoch says drier weather conditions that have spread across many cropping regions in the country and the prevailing El Nino climate outlook are playing a significant role in the tighter supply outlook for Australian grain and oilseeds.

Production expectations are varied across regions with some farmers expecting to see elevated production due to positive growing conditions they have experienced while others will be facing tough decisions as to whether it will be worth harvesting their crop, he said.
The bank says all cereal and coarse grain production  including wheat, barley and oats  is expected to decrease this season, with wheat declining the furthest, down to 26.9 million tonnes.
Winter crop production is expected to decline across all states, except Victoria, where the bank sees it rising by eight per cent from last year.

image.altText: A composite image ofBrandon Zerk-Thatcher, Esava Ratugolea and Xavier Duursma.

items.synopsis: With only two days left, negotiations are getting frosty with clubs scrambling to get their work done before the end of AFL trade period. Get the latest news, analysis and discussion in our live blog.

title.children: Port Adelaide makes draft threat as AFL trade period reaches crucial penultimate day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reports across the board confirm the first deal of the day is officially done, and Shane McAdam has had his wish granted. The Dees and Crows come to an agreement to send the forward to Melbourne, with the AFL set to confirm the trade shortly. Melbourne have traded a future second round pick to Adelaide for Shane McAdam. So this is the deal that the Demons have had on the table for quite some time, but all the while the Crows have been trying to prise Harrison Petty out of Melbourne. Once it became clear that was impossible, this rather simple deal has been done.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Shane McAdam has been traded to Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)

Reports across the board confirm the first deal of the day is officially done, and Shane McAdam has had his wish granted. The Dees and Crows come to an agreement to send the forward to Melbourne, with the AFL set to confirm the trade shortly.
Melbourne have traded a future second round pick to Adelaide for Shane McAdam.

So this is the deal that the Demons have had on the table for quite some time, but all the while the Crows have been trying to prise Harrison Petty out of Melbourne. Once it became clear that was impossible, this rather simple deal has been done.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet. Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say: Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen  though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Port Adelaide's busy two days

children.content: (Getty Images)
There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet.
Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say:
Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong
Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma
Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen  though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond
Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night
Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.

image.altText: girl in tent

items.synopsis: The 16-year-old'sfamily moved out of their rental home when it went up for sale in the middle of this year. Now, they are living in a tent about an hour away from her school.

title.children: Maddison's family pays $360 a week to live in a tent. She worries about her education and safety

image.altText: A man and woman look at paperwork while sitting at an outdoor wooden table

items.synopsis: The competition between mortgage lenders to get your business could soon be heating up again, analysts say, as the nation's largest lender loses market share for the first time in five years.

title.children: Will we soon see 'mortgage wars' part two as the nation's biggest bank bleeds customers?

items.synopsis: Detectives probing a 20-year-old cold case murder of a Gold Coast bottle shop managersaythe same people are responsible for the fatal shooting of another man.

title.children: $1m reward offered in Gold Coast cold case murders 'linked' by red car

image.altText: A peregrine falcon in a nest box feeds her two fluffy white chicks.

items.synopsis: For the past 15 years, falcon lovers around the world have watched on with joy andat times heartbreak at the private lives of a peregrine falcon family live streamed for a university project.

title.children: 'No filter, no editing': Global audience hooked as falcon family welcomes new chicks

items.synopsis: Thousands of patients are at riskas reserves of fuel across Gaza hospitals are expected to last 24 more hours,with ice cream trucks being used as back up morgues as cemeteriesrun out of space.

title.children: Hamas says ground invasion 'doesn't scare us' as it reveals about 250 hostages being held

image.altText: a amn who regularly swam at nielsen park in sydney looks through the mesh that covers the site as remedial work is done

items.synopsis: The National Parks and Wildlife Service (NPWS) closed Neilson Park's Shark Beachin the city's east in early 2022, after its 100-year-old seawall was damaged in a 2016 storm.

title.children: 'Treasured' Sydney beach set for another summer without swimmers

image.altText: A man standing outside NT Parliament House and looking serious.

items.synopsis: The Local Government Minister says he made the decision because he was satisfied "there are, or may be, serious deficiencies in the conduct of the Council's affairs".

title.children: NT Government suspends Barkly Regional Council, places it under 'official management'

image.altText: Adrian paces his caged outdoor space

items.synopsis: Concerns about the "cruel, inhuman and degrading" treatment of a man with an intellectual disability has prompted a complaint.

title.children: Human rights complaint lodged over 'cruel' treatment, indefinite detention of Brisbane man

image.altText: An old colour photo of a young man sitting in bushland with no shirt on

items.synopsis: For more than two years, Shane Tapp's family haspushed for more information surrounding his death by the Katherine River in the Northern Territory.

title.children: 'A human being that deserved better': Shane Tapp's family hope inquest will deliver answers

image.altText: A man and woman stand inside a tunnel.

items.synopsis: Outreach workers Ada Watson and Ayden McMahon are atthe coalface of the homelessness crisis, watching over rough sleepers like Ray Farquhar andworking to helpthe desperate and the vulnerable.

title.children: Compassion, solace and a barbecue  on the frontline with the guardian angels of the rough sleepers
